intro: Brassica saruna, commonly known as the wild mustard, is a flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring erect stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and hairy. Its small, yellow flowers are arranged in racemes and bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees. The plant produces small, round pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind or animals.
